abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts. Some of the lessons suggested follows.
            There should be agreement on a coherent results chain, and
            appropriate performance indicators should be chosen in line
            with objectives, using them for systematic monitoring, and
            regular discussion implementation performance with the
            government. It is emphasized that "Ownership"
            should be actively demanded as the pre-condition for further
            advancement of the project at agreed milestones, especially
            as key reforms are concerned. Also emphasized is the fact
            that if project components and sub-components are of an
            experimental nature or, innovations, lessons should be drawn
            early on to derive the full project benefits. For
            sub-sectors with small credit allocation, the objective -
            innovation/experimentation or improved access and quality -
            should be clearly identified. Regarding decentralization,
            decisions should be taken at each level; involving
            implementing units at an early stage, and trial innovations
            experimented prior to large-scale investments. It is
            stipulated decentralization at the school-level projects is
            unrealistic - the numbers are too large to manage effectively.

5077313.majtheme: Public sector governance,Rural development,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education Sector Development Project
            for Madagascar aims to produce more and better trained
            students at all levels of education at sustainable cost. The
            project components are five. The first universalizes quality
            primary education by supporting community and school-based
            projects that improve access and learning outcomes by a)
            supporting services to prepare, sign, monitor, and evaluate
            contracts, b) providing quality inputs to improve school
            management, teaching processes, and staff development; and
            c) rehabilitating infrastructure and supplying furniture and
            equipment. The second improves quality of and access to
            secondary education, particularly in rural areas, by
            supporting school-based pilot programs with subcomponents
            similar to those of the first component. The third component
            improves access to quality textbooks and teacher-learning
            materials to primary schools by a) producing new titles
            including teaching guides; b) printing and distributing
            textbooks and teaching materials; and c) holding in-service
            teacher training. The fourth component strengthens key
            functions in the education ministry at central and local
            levels including educational planning, bi-annual learning
            assessments and financial management strengthening, and
            pre-investment studies. The fifth component supports reform
            of higher education in assisting institutions to modernize
            and to diversify.
